# edar

<!-- badges: start -->
[![R-CMD-check](https://github.com/soutomas/edar/actions/workflows/R-CMD-check.yaml/badge.svg)](https://github.com/soutomas/edar/actions/workflows/R-CMD-check.yaml)

[![](http://cranlogs.r-pkg.org/badges/edar)](https://cran.r-project.org/package=edar)

The goal of edar is to provide some convenient functions to facilitate common tasks in exploratory data analysis.

## Citation

Sou T (2025). _edar: Convenient Functions for Exploratory Data Analysis_. R package version 0.0.5.9000, <https://github.com/soutomas/edar>.

```{r}
citation("edar")
```

## Installation

``` r
# From CRAN 
install.packages("edar")

# From GitHub - for the latest development version
# install.packages("pak")
pak::pak("soutomas/edar")
```

## Example

Commonly, we want to generate a quick summary of variables in a dataset. 

```{r}
library(edar)

# Data 
dat = mtcars |> dplyr::mutate(vs=factor(vs), am=factor(am))

# Summaries of all continuous variables in a data frame. 
dat |> summ_by()

# Summaries of a selected variable after grouping. 
dat |> summ_by(mpg,vs)
dat |> summ_by(mpg,vs,am)

# Summaries of all categorical variables in a data frame. 
dat |> summ_cat()

```

Results can be directly viewed in a flextable object.  

```{r eval=FALSE}
# Show data frame in a flextable object. 
dat |> summ_by(mpg,vs) |> ft()
```

It is often helpful to add a label in the output indicating the source file. 

```{r eval=FALSE}
# A label indicating the current source file with run time can be easily generated for annotation. 
lab = label_src()
```

```{r eval=FALSE}
# A source label can be directly added to the flextable output. 
dat |> summ_by(mpg,vs) |> ft(src=1)
```

```{r fig.width=5, fig.height=4, eval=FALSE}
# A source label can be directly added to a ggplot object. 
library(ggplot2)
p = ggplot(mtcars, aes(mpg, wt)) + geom_point() 
p |> ggsrc()
```
